keyTakeAways: Federal officials, including Customs and Border Protection (CBP) and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), are under judicial review for allegedly violating a federal judge’s order restricting the use of tear gas and less-lethal force during protests in Chicago.

Judge Sara Ellis, an Obama appointee, issued a sweeping order requiring body-worn cameras and limiting crowd control tactics, citing concerns over the deployment of tear gas without warning and lack of transparency.

Officials have defended their actions, asserting that agents are wearing body cameras and that no tear gas was deployed without warning, though the judge remains unconvinced and demands more accountability.

Operation Midway Blitz, a recent ICE deployment targeting migrants in Chicagoland, resulted in over 1,000 arrests and triggered public protests, including demonstrations at the Broadview ICE facility where over 100 protesters gathered and 15 were arrested on Friday and at least 15 more on Saturday.

The judge has ordered that key figures, such as ICE interim head Russell Hott and CBP chief patrol agent Gregory Bovino, must be deposed later to provide full context on events, despite Hott leaving Chicago for Washington, D.C.

Federal officials have claimed that media reports about tear gas use are one-sided and edited, but the judge maintains that her order must be followed, and she will continue to demand answers until compliance is demonstrated.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A federal judge, Sara Ellis, is demanding accountability from federal immigration enforcement agencies—specifically Customs and Border Protection (CBP) and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE)—for allegedly violating her order restricting the use of tear gas and less-lethal force during protests in Chicago. The judge, an Obama appointee, issued a sweeping order requiring body-worn cameras and specific limits on crowd control tactics, citing concerns that agents deployed tear gas without warning and violated transparency standards. Federal officials, including CBP Deputy Incident Commander Kyle Harvick and ICE Deputy Field Office Director Shawn Byers, testified that agents are wearing body cameras and that no tear gas was used without warning, though the judge remains unconvinced and has ordered the deposition of key figures like former ICE interim head Russell Hott and CBP chief patrol agent Gregory Bovino. The controversy stems from Operation Midway Blitz, a Trump administration-led deployment that resulted in over 1,000 arrests of migrants across Illinois between September 8 and October 3, triggering protests at the Broadview ICE facility. Protests have continued, with over 100 demonstrators gathering and 15 arrests reported in recent days. The judge insists on full transparency, stating that her order must be followed and that the government must provide verifiable answers to her concerns.
title: Federal officials try to reassure judge they’re following her orders to tone down and record Chicagoland protest actions
